awd_titl_txt: Vision and Change for Geoscience Undergraduate Education: Report and Toolkit
awd_abstract_narration:
Significant changes in geoscience research and geoscience career opportunities have occurred over the past two decades, and for the most part, undergraduate geoscience curricula and programs have not kept up with these changes. Thus, students from many colleges and universities leave undergraduate programs without the necessary educational products to successfully engage in geoscience employment or for attending graduate school. As a result of the multi-year effort on the Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education (Futures), the skills competencies and concepts that students need to be successful in the current and future workforce have been defined and agreed on by both the academic and employer components of the geoscience community.  In addition to developing a consensus, the Futures effort investigated best practices for imparting these core needs to students and implementing changes within geoscience departments across the country. The current project will develop a Vision and Change document and toolkit for the geosciences that encapsulates all of the results and outcomes from the Futures effort. Department heads, chairs, and other administrators, faculty, students and employers will have access to the document and toolkit to guide systematic changes in geoscience education at the undergraduate level in the United States. The education of undergraduate students in departments that successfully evolve their programs will be greatly enhanced, and those students will be better prepared for graduate school and/or future employment.  The experiential learning recommended by the wider geoscience academic and employment community is also most conducive to learning by underrepresented groups and to their future success.

The Vision and Change document will make the case for the critical need for institutional change and provide guidance on best practices for achieving these changes for departments of different sizes and institution types. The current project will produce a suite of information products to be used as a tool set for deans, department chairs, and faculty in assessing their existing curriculum and guiding the priorities and strategies for modernizing their program to meet current and emerging needs. The Vision and Change document and associated products will provide critical data on the skills, concepts and competencies needed for undergraduate geoscience education and on effective strategies for updating undergraduate curricula and programs and in identifying common obstacles or roadblocks and solutions. Results from previous pilot studies at different institution types and faculty levels will be presented to help departments identify the approaches that would be most beneficial to them. Preparing students to be successful future geoscientists requires a solid understanding of current and future workforce needs and the evolution of curricula and programs to keep in step with the changes in geoscience research and technology.  Fomenting change in departments, particularly with respect to undergraduate curricula, can be a challenge and being able to design successful strategies for changing undergraduate programs in different types of institutions will be a significant advancement. The Vision and Change document will be a catalyst for change and provide a roadmap for proven pathways to success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Vision and Change for Geoscience Undergraduate Education: Report and Toolkit project's major focus was the development of a report and tools to make the findings from The Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education initiative actionable to facilitate the evolution of undergraduate geoscience education.  The report captures and details the geoscience community's vision for the concepts, skills and competencies undergraduate students need for graduate school and future careers as detailed by both academic and industry geoscientists.  Additionally, case studies illustrating best practices and strategies of departments that have implemented these recommended changes into their undergraduate programs are detailed to provide proven roadmaps to change.

This project had several major components:

  • Analysis of the surveys, summits, workshops, and progress reports from the Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education project, which represented the experiences and input of over 1000 geoscience faculty and professionals.
  • Development of a comprehensive publication providing the community's vision of the future geoscience undergraduate educational experience.
  • Demonstration how the findings from the Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education project support this community vision and provide recommendations for implementation strategies.
  • Identify pedagogical, professional development, and institutional change best practices to support the recommendations.
  • Coalesce these findings into a comprehensive report and supporting materials for publication and distribution throughout the geoscience community
  • Develop a companion online toolkit, composed of primarily the resulting data compendium from all surveys, summits, and workshops as well as anonymized versions of case studies and progress reports provided by participating departments and faculty in the original summit series.

Using the guiding questions addressed by the Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education, the Vision and Change document covers the following topics:

  • What should undergraduate geoscience education accomplish (core concepts, skills and competencies for success).
  • How to implement curriculum reform
  • Assessment of student learning outcomes
  • Recruiting, retaining and promoting success of undergraduate students with emphasis on students underrepresented in the geosciences
  • Leveraging the Next Generation Science Standards in introductory and non-major courses to recruit majors and prepare K-12 science or geoscience Teachers
  • Building a continuum for lifelong learning
  • What graduate geoscience education in Earth, atmospheric and ocean sciences should accomplish
  • Fostering change in the academic community: case studies

Additionally, it includes an executive summary, call to action, engaging stakeholders, summary of process, as well as 4 Appendices.

All members of the advisory committee volunteered to serve as contributing writers for the Vision and Change document, and were active collaborators with the PIs.  Each committee member brought specific expertise, such as 2YC, diversity, professional development, pedagogical practices, and organizational change.  As such, those parts of the document were led by the appropriate committee member.

The project process included full analysis by the PIs of the results for surveys, summits, workshops and case studies during the preceding study.  Additionally, the contributing advisory committee was tasked to synthesis the community inputs and learnings into fully-supported, detailed recommendations and goals for the future of geoscience undergraduate education as well as suggested approaches and strategies.

The final document was fully reviewed, designed, and disseminated to all U.S. geoscience faculty, leadership of geoscience societies, and individuals from geoscience employers who are active with American Geoscience Institute initiatives - over 34,000 individuals in total.

Additionally, the document and online toolkit have become a key reference to both undergraduate and graduate students who approach AGI's workforce program seeking advice on what they should be expecting from their geoscience programs.

Initial feedback from chairs and faculty have been very positive, with many noting that the disruptions imposed by the pandemic has enabled more active implementation of the recommendations from the project as part of the new approaches to teaching being required.

The resulting report and toolkit are available at https://www.americangeosciences.org/change.
